Disease: A Guide to Clinical Trials for Cancer
Explanation: A patient-oriented overview of how cancer clinical trials work, including phases, ethics, consent, and access.
Suggestion: Useful for patients considering new therapies.

Disease: A Guide to Help Children Understand Cancer
Explanation: Educational material designed to explain cancer in a child-friendly way.
Suggestion: Use in pediatric settings or family counseling.

Explanation: Overview of plant-based treatments, benefits, risks, and regulatory concerns.
Suggestion: Always consult a doctor before replacing standard medicine.
IsTestOrDoctorRequired: Sometimes; depends on condition being treated

Explanation: Measures average blood glucose over 2–3 months; key diabetes diagnostic test.
Causes: High sugar intake, insulin resistance, genetic predisposition
Symptoms: Often asymptomatic; used to monitor known diabetes

Explanation: Rare genetic disorder affecting facial, skeletal, and genital development, more common in males.
Symptoms: Short stature, widely spaced eyes, hernias, delayed puberty
Treatment: Supportive therapy, growth hormone in some cases

Explanation: Rare congenital disorder marked by anemia and skeletal deformities.
Symptoms: Pale skin, triphalangeal thumbs, cleft palate, joint deformities
Treatment: Blood transfusion, corticosteroids, bone marrow transplant (severe)

Explanation: Swelling or bloating of the abdomen due to gas, fluid, organ enlargement, or masses.
Treatment: Based on cause — e.g., diuretics, surgery, antibiotics

Explanation: Bulging or dilation in the abdominal aorta, risk of rupture if untreated.
Symptoms: Often none; large aneurysms may cause pain or pulsing sensation
Treatment: Surgical repair if >5 cm; monitoring if small

Explanation: Surgical procedure to correct a large aneurysm through abdominal incision.

Disease: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Repair - Open - Discharge
Explanation: Post-op care following open aneurysm repair; focuses on wound care, activity limits.
A feeling of fullness or swelling in the abdomen, often due to excess gas or digestive issues.
Causes: Gas, indigestion, constipation, irritable bowel syndrome, food intolerances.
Treatment: Dietary changes, medications to reduce gas, treatment of underlying causes.

Explanation: Imaging test that provides detailed pictures of the abdomen for diagnosis of diseases or injuries.
Suggestion: Usually requested by doctor to evaluate abdominal issues.

Explanation: Surgical procedure to examine the abdominal cavity to diagnose or treat conditions.
Causes: Suspected internal injury, unexplained abdominal pain.

Explanation: Measurement of abdominal circumference, used to assess abdominal distension or obesity.
Suggestion: Used as a clinical monitoring tool.

Explanation: Palpable lump or swelling in the abdomen, which may be benign or malignant.
Symptoms: Visible or palpable lump, pain, discomfort.
Treatment: Depends on diagnosis; surgery, antibiotics, chemotherapy.

Explanation: Magnetic resonance imaging to obtain detailed images of abdominal organs and tissues.
Causes: Diagnostic evaluation of tumors, inflammation, or vascular issues.

Explanation: Discomfort or pain anywhere in the abdominal area caused by various conditions.
Treatment: Depends on cause; analgesics, antibiotics, surgery.
Suggestion: Seek immediate care if severe or persistent.

Explanation: Pain localized or generalized in the abdomen of children, often with varied causes.
Symptoms: Crying, irritability, refusal to eat, vomiting.
Treatment: Depends on diagnosis; hydration, rest, medications.

Explanation: Post-treatment care instructions after radiation therapy to the abdomen.

Tests.Name: Routine blood tests, imaging as advised

Explanation: A condition where abdominal muscles involuntarily contract and become hard, often indicating peritonitis.
Noises made by the movement of the intestines, normally indicating digestive activity.
Treatment: Depends on cause; hydration, dietary changes.
Suggestion: Report if associated with pain or constipation.

Explanation: Also called paracentesis, procedure to remove fluid from the abdominal cavity.
Causes: Ascites due to liver disease, infection, cancer.
Suggestion: Performed by trained physician under sterile conditions.

Explanation: Emergency procedure (Heimlich maneuver) used to expel airway obstruction.
Treatment: Immediate abdominal thrusts to dislodge object.
Suggestion: Learn CPR and emergency first aid.
IsTestOrDoctorRequired: If incident occurs, seek medical care.

Explanation: Non-invasive imaging to assess abdominal organs and structures.
Causes: Diagnostic evaluation for pain, masses, fluid.
Suggestion: Widely available and safe imaging method.

Explanation: Procedure to extract fat tissue for diagnostic purposes, often for amyloidosis.
Surgical intervention on the muscles and tissues of the abdominal wall (e.g., hernia repair).
X-ray imaging of the abdomen to assess bowel gas patterns, obstruction, perforation.
Tests to detect abnormal hemoglobin variants like sickle cell or thalassemia.
Causes: Genetic mutations affecting hemoglobin structure or production.
Treatment: Supportive, blood transfusions, bone marrow transplant in severe cases.

Explanation: Irregular or excessive bleeding from the uterus not related to normal menstruation.
Causes: Hormonal imbalance, uterine fibroids, polyps, infections, cancer.
Symptoms: Heavy bleeding, bleeding between periods, prolonged periods.
Treatment: Depends on cause; hormonal therapy, surgery.

Explanation: Changes in skin pigmentation leading to darker or lighter patches.
Causes: Sun exposure, hormonal changes, vitiligo, infections.
Treatment: Depends on cause; topical treatments, phototherapy.

Explanation: Condition where a mother’s blood type is incompatible with her baby’s, potentially causing hemolytic disease of the newborn.
Causes: Difference in blood groups between mother and fetus.
Treatment: Phototherapy, exchange transfusion in severe cases.

Explanation: Use of drugs to terminate a pregnancy medically.
Suggestion: Must be done under medical supervision.

Explanation: Surgical method of terminating pregnancy, such as dilation and curettage (D&C).
Care and monitoring following abortion procedure.
Localized collection of pus caused by infection.
Pus collection in the abdominal or pelvic cavity.
Condition where an individual does not produce sweat (anhidrosis).
Type of epilepsy causing brief lapses in consciousness.
Failure to start menstruation by age 15.
Cessation of menstruation for 3 months or more after menarche.
Rare congenital heart defect with missing pulmonary valve causing blood flow issues.
Skin condition with dark, thick, velvety patches in body folds.
Symptoms: Darkened skin patches, usually neck and armpits.
Suggestion: Lifestyle changes to manage weight and diabetes.

Explanation: Blood test measuring angiotensin-converting enzyme, elevated in sarcoidosis and other diseases.
Suggestion: Used in diagnosis of granulomatous diseases.

Explanation: Class of drugs that lower blood pressure by inhibiting angiotensin-converting enzyme.
Suggestion: Monitor kidney function and potassium levels.

Explanation: Toxicity due to excessive intake of acetaminophen (paracetamol) and codeine causing liver damage and respiratory depression.
Treatment: Emergency care, activated charcoal, N-acetylcysteine for acetaminophen poisoning.

Tests.Name: Blood acetaminophen levels, liver function tests

Explanation: Recommended safe dosing guidelines for acetaminophen (paracetamol) in pediatric patients to avoid toxicity.
Excess acetaminophen intake causing liver toxicity.
Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, liver failure.

Tests.Name: Liver function tests, acetaminophen blood levels

Explanation: Toxicity caused by ingestion or inhalation of acetone, a solvent found in products like nail polish remover.
Suggestion: Avoid exposure, seek medical help if exposed.

Explanation: Autoantibodies against acetylcholine receptors, associated with myasthenia gravis.
Disorder where the esophagus fails to move food into the stomach due to nerve damage.
Common musculoskeletal discomforts experienced due to hormonal and physical changes.
Inflammation of the Achilles tendon causing heel pain.
Surgical procedure to repair a ruptured Achilles tendon.
Symptoms: Sudden heel pain, inability to walk properly.

Explanation: Post-surgical or conservative care following Achilles tendon rupture.
Rare genetic disorder causing severe skeletal abnormalities and dwarfism.
Common genetic cause of dwarfism characterized by short limbs and normal torso size.
Symptoms: Short stature, bowed legs, spinal stenosis.

Explanation: A test to measure the kidneys' ability to acidify urine after acid loading.
Causes: Used to diagnose renal tubular acidosis.

Explanation: Complex carbohydrates in connective tissues; abnormal levels linked to certain metabolic disorders.
Treatment: Supportive; enzyme replacement therapy in some cases.

Explanation: Toxicity from inhaling or ingesting acid flux used in soldering.
Laboratory staining technique used to detect acid-fast bacteria like Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
Excess acidity in blood and body tissues.
Causes: Kidney failure, diabetic ketoacidosis, respiratory disorders.
Treatment: Treat underlying cause, bicarbonate therapy if needed.

Explanation: Surgical procedure to replace torn anterior cruciate ligament in the knee.
Postoperative care after ACL surgery.
Common skin condition causing pimples, blackheads, and cysts.
Causes: Hormonal changes, bacteria, excess oil production.

Explanation: Management of mild acne at home.
Benign tumor on the vestibulocochlear nerve affecting hearing and balance.
Damage to the ear due to sudden loud noise exposure.
Treatment: Avoid further exposure, corticosteroids in acute phase.
Suggestion: Use ear protection in noisy environments.

Explanation: Disorder where platelets do not function properly, causing bleeding.
Rare genetic disorder characterized by abnormalities in bone development.
Symptoms: Short fingers and toes, facial abnormalities.

Explanation: Disorder caused by excess growth hormone after puberty.
Symptoms: Enlarged hands and feet, facial changes.

Explanation: Test to measure the level of adrenocorticotropic hormone, which regulates cortisol production.
Causes: Used to diagnose adrenal disorders, Cushing’s disease, Addison’s disease.

Explanation: Test to check adrenal gland function by measuring cortisol response after ACTH administration.
Causes: Diagnose adrenal insufficiency or Addison’s disease.

Explanation: Rough, scaly patch on the skin caused by years of sun exposure; precancerous skin lesion.
Symptoms: Scaly, crusty patches on sun-exposed skin.
Suggestion: Dermatologist evaluation is important to prevent progression to skin cancer.

Explanation: Rare bacterial infection causing chronic abscesses and fibrosis, often in the face or neck.
Causes: Actinomyces bacteria normally found in mouth but cause infection if mucosa is breached.

Explanation: Life-threatening condition due to sudden adrenal insufficiency causing low cortisol.
Causes: Addison’s disease, sudden withdrawal of steroids, stress.
Symptoms: Severe weakness, low blood pressure, confusion, vomiting.
Treatment: Emergency intravenous hydrocortisone, fluids, electrolyte correction.

Explanation: Inflammation of the bronchial tubes usually caused by viral infections.
Treatment: Rest, fluids, symptomatic treatment; antibiotics rarely needed.
Suggestion: Avoid smoking, consult if symptoms persist beyond 3 weeks.

Explanation: Sudden inflammation of the gallbladder, often due to gallstones blocking the cystic duct.
Symptoms: Right upper abdominal pain, fever, nausea, vomiting.
Treatment: Hospital admission, antibiotics, pain relief, possible gallbladder removal.

Explanation: A range of urgent heart conditions caused by sudden reduced blood flow to the heart muscle.
Symptoms: Chest pain, shortness of breath, sweating.
Treatment: Hospital emergency care, medications, possible angioplasty or surgery.

Explanation: Sudden loss of kidney function causing buildup of toxins and fluids.
A type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow that affects white blood cells.
Causes: Genetic mutations, radiation exposure, environmental factors.
Symptoms: Fatigue, fever, easy bruising, bone pain, infections.
Treatment: Chemotherapy, radiation therapy, bone marrow transplant.
Medicines: Chemotherapeutic agents such as methotrexate, vincristine.

Explanation: Illness caused by rapid exposure to high altitude, resulting in low oxygen levels.
Causes: Rapid ascent above 2500 meters without acclimatization.
Symptoms: Headache, nausea, dizziness, fatigue, shortness of breath.
Treatment: Descent to lower altitude, oxygen therapy, medications.
Suggestion: Avoid rapid ascent; seek medical care if severe.

Explanation: Cancer of the blood and bone marrow characterized by rapid growth of abnormal white blood cells.
Causes: Genetic mutations, exposure to chemicals or radiation.

Explanation: Cancer of the blood and bone marrow in children with rapid proliferation of immature white blood cells.
Inflammation of the kidneys resulting in hematuria, hypertension, and reduced kidney function.
Symptoms: Blood in urine, swelling, high blood pressure.
Treatment: Supportive care, blood pressure control, treat underlying cause.

Explanation: Sudden inflammation of the pancreas causing severe abdominal pain.
Symptoms: Severe upper abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting.
Treatment: Hospitalization, fasting, IV fluids, pain control.

Explanation: Severe lung condition causing widespread inflammation and respiratory failure.
Symptoms: Severe shortness of breath, low oxygen levels.

Explanation: Kidney injury due to damage to tubule cells, leading to acute kidney failure.
Chronic adrenal insufficiency causing inadequate production of cortisol and aldosterone.
Symptoms: Fatigue, weight loss, low blood pressure, hyperpigmentation.

Explanation: Surgical procedure to remove adenoids, usually performed in children with recurrent infections or breathing problems.
Symptoms: Nasal obstruction, snoring, recurrent ear infections.
Medicines: Postoperative pain relievers, antibiotics if needed.

Explanation: Condition where endometrial tissue grows into the muscular wall of the uterus causing pain and heavy bleeding.
Causes: Exact cause unknown; may be linked to childbirth or uterine surgery.
Symptoms: Heavy menstrual bleeding, painful periods, pelvic pain.
Treatment: Pain management, hormonal therapy, hysterectomy in severe cases.

Explanation: Bands of scar tissue that form between organs and tissues, often after surgery or inflammation.
Emotional or behavioral reaction to a stressful event or change.
Physical, emotional, and psychological changes occurring during puberty.
Symptoms: Growth spurts, mood swings, sexual maturation.

Explanation: Preparation guidance for adolescents undergoing medical tests or procedures.
Causes: Routine health care or diagnostic work.

Explanation: Surgical removal of one or both adrenal glands (adrenalectomy), typically for tumors or hyperplasia.
Treatment: Surgery and hormonal replacement if bilateral removal.

Explanation: Small glands above kidneys producing hormones like cortisol, aldosterone, adrenaline.
Toxic effect due to excess use of bronchodilators causing increased heart rate and tremors.
Causes: Excessive use of medications like albuterol.

Explanation: Rare malignant tumor of the adrenal cortex causing hormone overproduction.
Symptoms: Abdominal pain, hormone-related symptoms (Cushing’s syndrome, virilization).

Explanation: A genetic disorder affecting the nervous system and adrenal glands, leading to progressive brain damage.
Causes: Mutation in the ABCD1 gene causing accumulation of very long-chain fatty acids.
Symptoms: Behavioral changes, muscle weakness, vision loss, adrenal insufficiency.
Treatment: No cure; symptom management, bone marrow transplant in early stages.

Explanation: A group of rare cancers originating from soft tissues like muscles, fat, nerves.
Symptoms: Painless lump or swelling, sometimes pain if pressing nerves.

Explanation: A rare inflammatory condition characterized by high fevers, joint pain, and rash.
Symptoms: Daily high fevers, salmon-colored rash, joint swelling.

Tests.Name: Blood tests (ESR, CRP, ferritin), exclusion of infections

Explanation: Legal documents outlining a person's wishes for medical treatment if they become unable to communicate.
Suggestion: Important for patients with chronic or terminal illness.

Explanation: Refers to processes or organisms that require oxygen.
Suggestion: Used in medical contexts like aerobic exercise or bacteria.

Explanation: Bacteria that require oxygen to survive and grow.
Toxic substances produced by certain fungi, contaminating food and causing liver damage.
Symptoms: Liver damage, jaundice, risk of liver cancer.
Suggestion: Avoid contaminated food; liver specialist care if exposed.

Tests.Name: Liver function tests, aflatoxin level testing

Disease: After a C-section - in the hospital
Explanation: Care and monitoring after cesarean delivery to ensure healing and prevent complications.
Symptoms: Pain at incision site, bleeding, risk of infection.
Treatment: Pain management, wound care, mobility encouragement.

Disease: After a fall in the hospital
Explanation: Assessment and management following a patient fall to prevent injury.
Causes: Falls due to weakness, environment, medication side effects.
Treatment: Injury assessment, physical therapy if needed.

Disease: After an exposure to sharps or body fluids
Explanation: Protocol followed after potential exposure to bloodborne pathogens through needle sticks or body fluids.
Causes: Accidental needle stick, splash of body fluids.
Symptoms: Usually none immediately; risk of infection from HIV, Hepatitis B/C.
Medicines: Antiretrovirals for HIV PEP, vaccines for Hepatitis B.

Tests.Name: Baseline HIV, Hepatitis B and C tests

Explanation: Instructions and care plan after chemotherapy treatment.
Symptoms: Fatigue, nausea, hair loss, immune suppression.
Medicines: Anti-nausea drugs, pain relief, growth factors if needed.

Tests.Name: Blood counts, imaging as per protocol

Disease: After vaginal delivery - in the hospital
Explanation: Postpartum care after vaginal birth to ensure mother's recovery and baby's well-being.
Treatment: Pain relief, hygiene care, breastfeeding support.

Tests.Name: Vital signs, uterine check, newborn screening

Disease: After weight-loss surgery - what to ask your doctor
Explanation: Important information patients should seek post bariatric surgery for safe recovery and lifestyle adjustment.
Treatment: Nutritional counseling, wound care, physical activity guidance.
Suggestion: Regular follow-up with surgeon and dietitian.

Tests.Name: Blood tests for nutrition, imaging if complications suspected

Explanation: Toxicity caused by ingestion or excessive skin exposure to aftershave containing alcohol and other chemicals.
Treatment: Supportive care, activated charcoal if ingestion recent.

Explanation: A rare genetic disorder causing absence of immunoglobulins, leading to severe immunodeficiency.
Causes: Genetic mutation affecting B cell development.
Symptoms: Recurrent bacterial infections, failure to thrive.

Explanation: Progressive hearing loss associated with aging, usually sensorineural type.
Symptoms: Difficulty hearing conversations, especially in noisy environments.

Explanation: Degenerative condition affecting central vision due to damage of the macula in the retina.
Symptoms: Blurred or dark central vision, difficulty reading.
Treatment: Lifestyle changes, vitamins, injections in some cases.

Explanation: Natural redistribution of fat and loss of muscle tone with aging.

Disease: Aging changes in hair and nails
Explanation: With aging, hair becomes thinner, grayer, and nails may become brittle and grow slower.
Causes: Natural aging, decreased blood flow, nutritional changes.
Treatment: Good nutrition, hair care, nail moisturizing.

Explanation: Decline in production of various hormones such as estrogen, testosterone, growth hormone with age.
Treatment: Hormone replacement therapy in select cases.

Explanation: Immune system function declines with age, increasing infection risk.

Disease: Aging changes in organs, tissue and cells
Explanation: Cells and organs undergo functional decline and structural changes over time.
Skin loses elasticity, becomes thinner, dry, and prone to wrinkles.
Sleep patterns change, with lighter and shorter sleep cycles in older adults.
Causes: Changes in circadian rhythm, health conditions.
Medicines: Sleep aids only if necessary and short-term.

Disease: Aging changes in teeth and gums
Explanation: Gums may recede, teeth become more prone to decay and wear.

Disease: Aging changes in the bones - muscles - joints
Explanation: Bone density decreases, muscles lose mass, joints stiffen.
Treatment: Exercise, calcium and vitamin D, medications.

Explanation: Breasts may lose firmness and volume due to fat and glandular tissue loss.
Facial skin thins, loses elasticity; fat pads shrink causing wrinkles and sagging.
Causes: Natural aging, sun damage, lifestyle factors.

Disease: Aging changes in the female reproductive system
Explanation: Menopause causes cessation of menstruation, hormonal decline, vaginal atrophy.

Disease: Aging changes in the heart and blood vessels
Explanation: Arterial stiffening, decreased cardiac output, increased risk of hypertension.
Symptoms: Elevated blood pressure, reduced exercise tolerance.

Tests.Name: Blood pressure monitoring, ECG, lipid profile

Disease: Aging changes in the kidneys and bladder
Explanation: Reduced kidney function and bladder capacity leading to frequent urination.
Causes: Age-related nephron loss and muscle weakening.
Suggestion: Nephrologist or urologist consultation if severe.

Explanation: Decreased lung elasticity and muscle strength reducing respiratory efficiency.
Symptoms: Reduced exercise capacity, shortness of breath.

Disease: Aging changes in the male reproductive system
Explanation: Reduced testosterone levels causing decreased libido and erectile dysfunction.

Disease: Aging changes in the nervous system
Explanation: Slower nerve conduction, reduced cognitive function, and reflexes.
Medicines: No specific meds for normal aging.

Tests.Name: Cognitive testing, MRI brain if needed

Explanation: Decline in vision, hearing, taste, smell, and touch sensitivity.
Symptoms: Blurred vision, hearing loss, reduced taste.

Explanation: Blood pressure and heart rate variability change with age.
Symptoms: Higher blood pressure, slower heart rate response.

Disease: Aging spots - should you be concerned?
Explanation: Aging spots, also called liver spots or solar lentigines, are flat brown spots appearing on sun-exposed skin with age.
Causes: Prolonged sun exposure and skin aging.
Symptoms: Flat, brownish spots usually on hands, face, shoulders.
Treatment: Usually no treatment needed; cosmetic options available.
Suggestion: Use sunscreen to prevent new spots.

Explanation: Agitation is a state of restlessness and emotional distress that can occur in various medical or psychiatric conditions.
Causes: Anxiety, delirium, medication side effects, psychiatric disorders.
Treatment: Identify and treat underlying cause; calming measures.
Medicines: Sedatives or antipsychotics in severe cases.
Suggestion: Seek medical evaluation if severe or persistent.

Explanation: An anxiety disorder characterized by fear of situations where escape might be difficult.
Symptoms: Fear of crowds, open spaces, panic attacks.

Explanation: Severe reduction in granulocytes, increasing infection risk.
Treatment: Stop causative drug, antibiotics, supportive care.

Explanation: A rare genetic disorder affecting the brain and eyes, mainly in females.
Symptoms: Seizures, absent corpus callosum, eye abnormalities.
Treatment: Symptomatic management of seizures and development.

Explanation: Blood test measuring liver enzyme ALT to assess liver function.
Suggestion: Used to diagnose liver disease or damage.

Explanation: A genetic disorder characterized by lack of melanin pigment in skin, hair, and eyes.
Causes: Mutations in genes involved in melanin production.
Symptoms: Very light skin and hair, vision problems.
Treatment: No cure; protective measures for skin and eyes.

Explanation: Measures albumin protein level in blood to assess nutrition and liver/kidney function.
Suggestion: Used in diagnosis and monitoring of various conditions.

Explanation: Alcohol consumption during pregnancy can harm the developing fetus, leading to fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD).
Symptoms: Growth problems, facial abnormalities, intellectual disability in fetus.
Treatment: No cure; prevention by abstinence from alcohol during pregnancy.
Suggestion: Complete avoidance of alcohol during pregnancy.

Explanation: Guidelines and education on moderate alcohol consumption to reduce health risks.
Causes: Excessive alcohol intake leads to liver, heart, and mental health problems.
Symptoms: Depend on amount and pattern of use.
Suggestion: Follow recommended safe limits and seek help if needed.

Explanation: A medical condition characterized by an inability to control alcohol use despite negative consequences.
Symptoms: Craving, loss of control, withdrawal symptoms.

Explanation: Information and support services available for individuals with alcohol use disorder.
Suggestion: Refer to counseling centers and support groups.

Explanation: Symptoms occurring when a person dependent on alcohol suddenly stops drinking.
Causes: Abrupt cessation of alcohol in dependent individuals.

Explanation: A metabolic complication of chronic alcohol use characterized by acidosis and ketone accumulation.
Causes: Excessive alcohol intake combined with poor nutrition.
Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, rapid breathing.
Treatment: Intravenous fluids, glucose, correction of electrolytes.

Explanation: Liver damage caused by chronic excessive alcohol consumption.
Treatment: Alcohol cessation, supportive care, liver transplant in severe cases.
Medicines: No specific cure; vitamin supplements and management of complications.

Explanation: Nerve damage due to chronic alcohol use leading to pain and numbness.
Causes: Toxic effects of alcohol and nutritional deficiencies.
Symptoms: Burning pain, tingling, numbness in limbs.

Explanation: Measures aldolase enzyme levels to assess muscle damage or liver disease.
Causes: Used to detect muscle disorders, liver conditions.
Suggestion: Used to evaluate muscle or liver health.

Explanation: Measures aldosterone hormone level to diagnose adrenal gland disorders affecting blood pressure.
Treatment: Depends on cause; surgery or medication.

Explanation: Condition where blood pH is higher than normal, indicating excess base.
Treatment: Address underlying cause, restore acid-base balance.
Medicines: Depends on cause; may include IV fluids.

Explanation: Rare inherited disorder causing buildup of homogentisic acid leading to dark urine and arthritis.
Causes: Genetic mutation affecting metabolism of tyrosine.
Symptoms: Dark urine, joint pain, skin discoloration.
Treatment: No cure; symptom management and dietary restriction of tyrosine.

Explanation: Substances causing allergic reactions by triggering immune response.

Tests.Name: Skin prick test, blood IgE test

Explanation: Eye inflammation caused by allergic reaction to allergens.
Medicines: Antihistamine or mast cell stabilizer eye drops.

Explanation: Immune system hypersensitivity to harmless substances.
Treatment: Avoid allergens, antihistamines, epinephrine for anaphylaxis.

Explanation: An allergic reaction causing sneezing, congestion, runny nose due to allergens.
Causes: Pollen, dust mites, animal dander, mold.
Symptoms: Sneezing, nasal congestion, itchy nose, watery eyes.

Tests.Name: Skin prick test, blood IgE test

Explanation: Managing symptoms of allergic rhinitis at home.
Treatment: Avoid triggers, use saline nasal sprays, OTC antihistamines.
Suggestion: Maintain clean environment to reduce allergens.

Disease: Allergic rhinitis - what to ask your doctor - adult
Explanation: Important questions for adults with allergic rhinitis to discuss with doctors.
Suggestion: Ask about triggers, treatment options, allergy testing.

Disease: Allergic rhinitis - what to ask your doctor - child
Explanation: Questions parents should ask about their child’s allergic rhinitis.
Suggestion: Discuss symptoms, treatment plans, and preventive measures.

Explanation: Immune system reactions to foreign substances (allergens).
Dust is a common allergen triggering asthma and allergy symptoms.
Treatment: Dust avoidance, medications for allergy and asthma.

Explanation: Mold spores can trigger allergic reactions and worsen asthma.
Pollen allergens can cause seasonal allergies and asthma flare-ups.
Suggestion: Limit outdoor activity during high pollen days.

Explanation: Immunotherapy to reduce allergy symptoms by gradually increasing allergen exposure.
Causes: Used in patients with significant allergic reactions.

Explanation: Test to identify specific allergens causing allergic reactions.
Aloe vera is a plant used in herbal remedies for skin conditions and minor burns.
Suggestion: Use pure aloe vera for best results; avoid if allergic.

Explanation: An autoimmune disorder causing patchy hair loss on the scalp and body.

Tests.Name: Clinical examination, scalp biopsy if uncertain

Explanation: Measures alkaline phosphatase enzyme to evaluate liver and bone health.
Causes: Used in diagnosis of liver disease, bone disorders.

Explanation: Differentiates types of alkaline phosphatase to localize disease source.
Causes: Distinguishes bone vs liver ALP elevation.
Suggestion: Useful after ALP blood test abnormality.

Explanation: Blood test measuring AFP, used in screening liver cancer and fetal abnormalities.
Causes: Elevated in liver cancer, certain fetal conditions.
Suggestion: Used for cancer surveillance and prenatal screening.

Explanation: Measures alpha-1 antitrypsin protein to diagnose deficiency causing lung/liver disease.
Inherited disorder causing low levels of alpha-1 antitrypsin, leading to lung and liver disease.
Treatment: Smoking cessation, liver care, augmentation therapy.

Tests.Name: Alpha-1 antitrypsin blood test, genetic testing

Explanation: Genetic disorder causing progressive kidney disease, hearing loss, and eye abnormalities.
Symptoms: Blood in urine, hearing loss, vision problems.

Explanation: Information and support services for Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis patients.
Suggestion: Refer to ALS support groups and specialists.

Explanation: A rare genetic disorder characterized by progressive vision and hearing loss, heart disease, and diabetes.
Symptoms: Vision impairment, hearing loss, obesity, type 2 diabetes, cardiomyopathy.
Treatment: Symptomatic management and monitoring of complications.
Medicines: Medications to manage diabetes, heart conditions.

Tests.Name: Genetic testing, cardiac evaluation, audiology tests

Explanation: Use of non-conventional therapies such as acupuncture, herbal remedies, or massage to manage pain.
Suggestion: Consult qualified practitioners and disclose to your doctor.

Explanation: Conditions affecting the alveoli, the air sacs in the lungs, impairing gas exchange.
Treatment: Depends on underlying cause; antibiotics, steroids, oxygen therapy.

Tests.Name: Chest X-ray, CT scan, pulmonary function tests

Explanation: A progressive neurodegenerative disorder causing memory loss, cognitive decline, and behavioral changes.
Causes: Combination of genetic, environmental, and lifestyle factors.
Symptoms: Memory loss, confusion, difficulty in daily tasks.
Treatment: No cure; symptomatic treatment with medications and supportive care.
Suggestion: Early diagnosis and support are important.

Explanation: Information and support for patients and caregivers dealing with Alzheimer’s disease.
Suggestion: Refer to Alzheimer’s support groups, counseling.

Explanation: Guide to recognizing signs of labor in pregnant women.
Symptoms: Regular contractions, water breaking, lower back pain.
Suggestion: Contact healthcare provider when symptoms appear.

Explanation: Transient loss of vision in one eye due to temporary lack of blood flow to retina.
Symptoms: Sudden, brief vision loss or dimming.
Treatment: Address vascular risk factors, possible surgery.
Suggestion: Urgent evaluation needed to prevent stroke.

Tests.Name: Carotid Doppler, MRI brain, eye exam

Explanation: Condition in newborns where external genitalia are not clearly male or female.
Reduced vision in one eye due to abnormal visual development during childhood.
Suggestion: Early diagnosis essential for better outcomes.

Explanation: A parasitic infection caused by Entamoeba histolytica affecting the intestines and sometimes other organs.
Causes: Ingestion of contaminated food or water containing cysts of the parasite.
Symptoms: Diarrhea, abdominal pain, bloody stools, fever.
Treatment: Antiprotozoal medications like metronidazole and paromomycin.
Suggestion: Maintain good hygiene and safe drinking water.
DoctorType: Infectious disease specialist or general physician

Explanation: A collection of pus in the liver caused by Entamoeba histolytica infection spreading from intestines.
Causes: Invasion of liver tissue by the parasite after intestinal infection.
Symptoms: Fever, right upper abdominal pain, jaundice, weight loss.
Treatment: Antiprotozoal drugs, drainage if abscess is large.

Tests.Name: Ultrasound abdomen, liver function tests, serology

Explanation: A hereditary condition causing defective enamel formation on teeth.
Building blocks of proteins essential for bodily functions.
Suggestion: Balanced diet ensures adequate amino acids.

Explanation: Excess amino acids in urine indicating kidney or metabolic disorders.
Symptoms: May be asymptomatic or show symptoms of underlying disorder.
Treatment: Depends on cause; dietary management or treatment of kidney disease.

Explanation: Toxicity caused by excess aminophylline (bronchodilator) leading to cardiac and neurological symptoms.
Treatment: Supportive care, activated charcoal, anti-seizure medications.

Explanation: Toxic effects from excess ingestion of these psychiatric medications.
Treatment: Supportive care, activated charcoal, cardiac monitoring.

Explanation: Poisoning from excessive amitriptyline use, an antidepressant.
Treatment: Activated charcoal, supportive care, cardiac monitoring.

Explanation: Measures ammonia levels in blood to evaluate liver function and diagnose hepatic encephalopathy.
Suggestion: Test ordered when hepatic dysfunction suspected.

Explanation: Toxic condition caused by excessive ammonia in the body, leading to neurological symptoms.
Causes: Liver failure, urea cycle disorders, ingestion or exposure to ammonia.
Treatment: Reducing ammonia levels, supportive care, treating underlying cause.
Medicines: Lactulose, antibiotics to reduce ammonia-producing gut bacteria.

Tests.Name: Blood ammonia levels, liver function tests

Explanation: Poisoning due to ingestion or inhalation of ammonium hydroxide, causing chemical burns and respiratory distress.
Causes: Accidental or intentional exposure to cleaning agents containing ammonium hydroxide.
Symptoms: Burning sensation, difficulty breathing, nausea, vomiting.
Treatment: Immediate decontamination, supportive care, airway management.

Explanation: A prenatal diagnostic procedure to sample amniotic fluid for genetic and fetal health testing.
Causes: Performed to detect chromosomal abnormalities and infections.
Suggestion: Usually performed between 15-20 weeks of pregnancy.

Explanation: A congenital disorder where fibrous bands restrict fetal development causing limb or body deformities.
Causes: Disruption of amniotic sac during pregnancy.
Symptoms: Limb amputations, cleft palate, craniofacial anomalies.

Explanation: Fluid surrounding the fetus in the amniotic sac, protecting and supporting development.
Suggestion: Amniotic fluid levels monitored in pregnancy.

Tests.Name: Ultrasound assessment of amniotic fluid index

Explanation: Blood test measuring amylase enzyme to assess pancreas function and detect pancreatitis.
Causes: Used to diagnose acute pancreatitis and other pancreatic disorders.
Suggestion: Ordered when abdominal pain or pancreatic disease suspected.

Explanation: Urine test measuring amylase to help diagnose pancreatic disorders.
Causes: Used alongside blood amylase in pancreatic disease.

Explanation: A progressive neurodegenerative disease affecting motor neurons leading to muscle weakness and paralysis.
Causes: Mostly sporadic; some genetic mutations linked.
Treatment: No cure; supportive care and riluzole may slow progression.

Explanation: Refers to bacteria or processes that do not require oxygen to survive or occur.
Suggestion: Relevant in infections caused by anaerobic bacteria.

Explanation: Bacteria that thrive in environments without oxygen, often causing infections in deep wounds or abscesses.
Causes: Infections occur when anaerobic bacteria invade tissues with poor oxygen supply.
Treatment: Antibiotics effective against anaerobes, surgical drainage if needed.
Suggestion: Seek medical treatment for suspected infections.

Explanation: A small tear in the lining of the anus causing pain and bleeding during bowel movements.
Symptoms: Pain during defecation, bright red blood on stool or toilet paper.
Treatment: High-fiber diet, stool softeners, topical anesthetics, sometimes surgery.
Suggestion: Increase fiber and fluids; see doctor if persistent.

Explanation: Irritation causing itching around the anus, often from hygiene issues or minor infections.
Causes: Poor hygiene, moisture, skin irritation, hemorrhoids, infections.
Treatment: Improved hygiene, avoiding irritants, topical creams.
Medicines: Hydrocortisone cream, antifungal creams if needed.
Suggestion: Maintain dry, clean area; avoid scratching.

Explanation: Kidney damage caused by prolonged use of painkillers, especially combination analgesics.
Causes: Chronic overuse of analgesic medications like NSAIDs or acetaminophen combinations.
Treatment: Stop offending drugs, supportive kidney care.
Suggestion: Use pain medications judiciously and under medical supervision.

Explanation: A severe, life-threatening allergic reaction causing airway swelling, low blood pressure, and shock.
Causes: Allergic reaction to foods, insect stings, medications, or other allergens.
Symptoms: Rapid onset swelling, difficulty breathing, hives, low blood pressure.
Treatment: Immediate injection of epinephrine, emergency medical care.
Suggestion: Avoid known allergens and carry emergency epinephrine if at risk.

Explanation: A rare, aggressive form of thyroid cancer with poor prognosis.
Symptoms: Rapidly growing neck mass, difficulty swallowing, voice changes.

Explanation: A surgical connection between two structures, such as blood vessels or bowel segments.
Causes: Performed during surgery to restore continuity.

Explanation: A condition characterized by low red blood cell count or hemoglobin, leading to reduced oxygen delivery.
Causes: Iron deficiency, vitamin B12 deficiency, chronic disease, blood loss.
Symptoms: Fatigue, weakness, pale skin, shortness of breath.
Treatment: Treat underlying cause, iron/vitamin supplements, transfusions in severe cases.

Disease: Anemia caused by low iron - children
Explanation: Iron deficiency anemia in children due to inadequate iron intake or absorption.
Causes: Poor diet, rapid growth, chronic blood loss.
Suggestion: Regular pediatric check-ups and nutrition monitoring.

Disease: Anemia caused by low iron - infants and toddlers
Explanation: Iron deficiency anemia in young children caused by insufficient dietary iron or absorption issues.
Causes: Inadequate iron intake, early weaning from breast milk, chronic blood loss.
Symptoms: Pale skin, poor appetite, developmental delays, irritability.
Treatment: Iron supplementation, iron-rich diet, treatment of underlying causes.
Medicines: Iron drops or syrup formulated for infants.
Suggestion: Ensure proper nutrition and regular pediatric visits.

Explanation: A type of anemia occurring in people with chronic illnesses like infections, inflammation, or cancer, caused by impaired iron utilization.
Symptoms: Fatigue, weakness, pale skin, sometimes masked by underlying disease symptoms.
Treatment: Managing underlying disease, blood transfusions in severe cases.
Medicines: Iron supplements usually ineffective; erythropoiesis-stimulating agents may be used.
Suggestion: Regular monitoring and managing the chronic condition.

Explanation: A severe congenital condition where major parts of the brain and skull are missing, resulting in non-viable infants.
Causes: Neural tube defect during early fetal development, often linked to folic acid deficiency.
Symptoms: Absence of brain structures, incompatible with life.
Treatment: No cure; palliative care and supportive measures.
Suggestion: Folic acid supplementation in pregnancy to prevent.

Disease: Anesthesia - what to ask your doctor - adult
Explanation: Guidance on questions adults should ask healthcare providers before anesthesia to understand risks and preparation.
Suggestion: Discuss allergies, previous reactions, medications, and procedure details.

Disease: Anesthesia - what to ask your doctor - child
Explanation: Guidance for parents on questions to ask before their child undergoes anesthesia to ensure safety.
Suggestion: Discuss child's medical history, allergies, fasting guidelines, and risks.

Explanation: An abnormal bulge or ballooning in the wall of a blood vessel, which can rupture and cause life-threatening bleeding.
Symptoms: Often asymptomatic until rupture; may cause pain or pulsatile mass.
Suggestion: Regular monitoring if detected; control risk factors.

Explanation: A localized dilation of a cerebral artery that may rupture causing hemorrhagic stroke.
Symptoms: Sudden severe headache, nausea, vision problems, loss of consciousness if ruptured.
Medicines: Medications to control blood pressure and prevent complications.
Suggestion: Immediate medical attention if symptoms appear.

Tests.Name: CT angiography, MRI angiography, cerebral angiogram

Explanation: A genetic disorder causing developmental disabilities and neurological problems.
Causes: Loss of function of UBE3A gene on chromosome 15.
Symptoms: Severe developmental delays, speech impairment, seizures, happy demeanor.
Treatment: Symptomatic and supportive therapies including physical and speech therapy.
Suggestion: Early intervention improves quality of life.

Explanation: Chest pain or discomfort due to inadequate blood flow to the heart muscle.
Symptoms: Chest pressure, squeezing, pain often triggered by exertion or stress.
Treatment: Lifestyle changes, medications, and procedures to improve blood flow.
Suggestion: Seek prompt medical evaluation for chest pain.

Explanation: Guidance and care instructions provided after hospital discharge for patients treated for angina.
Suggestion: Adhere to medications, avoid triggers, attend follow-up appointments.

Disease: Angina - what to ask your doctor
Explanation: Important questions patients should ask their doctor about angina symptoms, treatment options, and lifestyle.
Suggestion: Discuss symptoms, risk factors, treatment plan and prognosis.

Disease: Angina - when you have chest pain
Explanation: What to do and how to manage chest pain related to angina.
Treatment: Rest, nitroglycerin, emergency care if severe or prolonged.
Suggestion: Seek immediate medical attention if pain is severe or lasts longer than 5 minutes.

Explanation: Abnormal, fragile blood vessels in the colon that can cause bleeding.
Causes: Age-related degeneration of blood vessels, chronic kidney disease.
Symptoms: Occult or overt rectal bleeding, anemia.
Treatment: Endoscopic coagulation, iron supplements, sometimes surgery.
Suggestion: Regular monitoring and management of bleeding.

Explanation: Rapid swelling of the deeper layers of skin, often around eyes and lips, sometimes life-threatening if airway is involved.
Causes: Allergic reactions, hereditary conditions, medications (ACE inhibitors).
Symptoms: Swelling, redness, difficulty breathing if airway involved.
Treatment: Antihistamines, corticosteroids, epinephrine in severe cases.
Suggestion: Avoid known triggers and seek emergency care if breathing difficulty occurs.

Explanation: Post-procedure care instructions following coronary angioplasty and stenting.
Treatment: Medications to prevent clotting, lifestyle changes.
Suggestion: Adhere to medications, avoid strenuous activity initially, attend follow-ups.

Disease: Angioplasty and stent placement - carotid artery
Explanation: Procedure to open narrowed carotid arteries to prevent stroke.
Symptoms: Often asymptomatic, may have transient ischemic attacks (TIA).
Suggestion: Monitor symptoms and control risk factors like hypertension.

Disease: Angioplasty and stent placement - carotid artery - discharge
Explanation: Instructions for care and follow-up after carotid artery angioplasty and stenting.
Suggestion: Attend follow-up appointments, report any neurological symptoms immediately.

Explanation: Procedure to treat coronary artery disease by opening blocked arteries using a balloon and placing a stent.
Treatment: Percutaneous coronary intervention with stent placement.
Suggestion: Lifestyle modifications and medication adherence post-procedure.

Disease: Angioplasty and stent placement - peripheral arteries
Explanation: Procedure to open narrowed or blocked peripheral arteries (usually legs) using balloon angioplasty and stent placement to improve blood flow.
Causes: Peripheral artery disease caused by atherosclerosis.
Symptoms: Leg pain when walking (claudication), cold feet, ulcers.
Treatment: Angioplasty with stent placement, lifestyle changes.
Suggestion: Quit smoking, manage diabetes and hypertension.

Disease: Angioplasty and stent placement - peripheral arteries - discharge
Explanation: Post-procedure care and instructions following peripheral artery angioplasty and stenting.
Treatment: Medication adherence, wound care, physical activity advice.
Suggestion: Avoid heavy activity initially, monitor for complications.

Explanation: Basic first aid and care steps after an animal bite to prevent infection and complications.
Causes: Bites from dogs, cats, rodents, or wild animals.
Symptoms: Pain, bleeding, swelling, risk of infection.
Treatment: Clean wound thoroughly, apply antiseptic, seek medical evaluation for tetanus and rabies risk.
Suggestion: Seek medical care especially if bite is deep or from wild animals.

Explanation: Unequal pupil sizes, which can be benign or indicate serious neurological issues.
Causes: Physiological variation, nerve damage, eye injury, brain injury.
Symptoms: Different pupil sizes, vision changes if severe.
Treatment: Depends on cause; urgent care if neurological.
Suggestion: Seek immediate medical care if sudden onset with other symptoms.

Explanation: Minimally invasive surgical procedure to diagnose or treat problems inside the ankle joint.
Causes: Used for ligament repairs, cartilage damage, removal of loose bodies.
Symptoms: Chronic ankle pain, swelling, limited movement.

Explanation: Guidelines for care following a broken ankle to promote healing and prevent complications.
Symptoms: Pain, swelling, bruising, inability to bear weight.
Suggestion: Elevate limb, physical therapy after healing.

Explanation: Discomfort or pain in the ankle region from various causes.
Suggestion: See doctor if pain is severe or persists.

Explanation: Surgical procedure replacing damaged ankle joint with artificial implants.
Suggestion: Rehabilitation and physical therapy after surgery.

Explanation: Post-surgical care instructions after ankle replacement surgery.
Treatment: Medication adherence, wound care, gradual weight bearing.

Explanation: Care procedures following an ankle sprain to reduce pain and swelling and promote healing.
Causes: Twisting or rolling of the ankle causing ligament injury.
Treatment: Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation (RICE), physical therapy.
Medicines: NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) for pain and inflammation.
Suggestion: Avoid weight bearing initially and follow rehab exercises.
IsTestOrDoctorRequired: Yes, if severe or persistent pain.

Explanation: Chronic inflammatory disease primarily affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints causing pain and stiffness.
Symptoms: Chronic back pain, stiffness worse in the morning, reduced spinal mobility.
Suggestion: Regular exercise and physical therapy are crucial.

Explanation: Congenital condition where pancreatic tissue encircles the duodenum causing obstruction.
Symptoms: Vomiting, abdominal pain, feeding intolerance in infants.
Treatment: Surgical bypass of the obstructed duodenum.

Disease: Anomalous left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery
Explanation: Rare congenital heart defect where left coronary artery arises from pulmonary artery instead of aorta, causing myocardial ischemia.
Symptoms: Heart failure symptoms in infancy, chest pain, arrhythmias.
Suggestion: Early diagnosis and surgical intervention crucial.

Explanation: Congenital absence of one or both testes.
Symptoms: Undescended or absent testes, delayed puberty.

Explanation: Infected cavity filled with pus near the anus or rectum.
Causes: Infection of anal glands, trauma, Crohn's disease.

Tests.Name: Physical examination, MRI if fistula suspected

Explanation: Eating disorder characterized by weight loss, distorted body image, and excessive dieting.
Symptoms: Extreme weight loss, fear of gaining weight, fatigue.

Explanation: Diagnostic procedures to visualize the anal canal and detect abnormalities.
Causes: Used in investigation of anal pain, bleeding, or lesions.

Explanation: Tear or sprain of the ACL, a major ligament in the knee joint.
Causes: Sudden twisting or impact injury during sports or accidents.
Treatment: Physical therapy, surgical reconstruction in severe cases.
Suggestion: Early diagnosis and rehab important for recovery.

Explanation: Post-treatment care following ACL injury or surgery to ensure proper healing and regain knee function.
Symptoms: Swelling, limited range of motion, pain.
Treatment: Physical therapy, gradual return to activity.
Suggestion: Follow rehab plan strictly, avoid strain.

Explanation: Pain located at the front of the knee, often related to overuse or alignment issues.
Symptoms: Dull aching pain around the kneecap, worsens with activity.
Suggestion: Avoid aggravating activities, strengthen surrounding muscles.

Explanation: Surgical procedure to correct vaginal wall prolapse or cystocele.
Causes: Childbirth trauma, aging, pelvic floor weakness.

Explanation: Serious infectious disease caused by Bacillus anthracis bacteria affecting skin, lungs, or intestines.
Causes: Contact with infected animals or spores.
Symptoms: Skin ulcers with black centers, fever, chest pain.
Treatment: Antibiotics such as ciprofloxacin or doxycycline.
Suggestion: Avoid exposure to livestock and animal products.

Explanation: Diagnostic test to detect anthrax infection by identifying bacteria or antibodies.
Blood test measuring antibodies against streptococcal DNase B enzyme to detect recent streptococcal infection.
Suggestion: Useful in diagnosing rheumatic fever or glomerulonephritis.

Explanation: Test to detect antibodies against the glomerular basement membrane, used to diagnose Goodpasture syndrome.
Causes: Autoimmune response damaging kidneys and lungs.
Symptoms: Blood in urine, cough, shortness of breath.
Suggestion: Early diagnosis essential to prevent kidney failure.

Explanation: Autoimmune disease where antibodies attack kidney and lung basement membranes causing damage.
Test to detect antibodies against insulin, relevant in autoimmune diabetes.
Causes: Used to diagnose type 1 diabetes or insulin autoimmune syndrome.

Explanation: Surgical procedure to prevent acid reflux by reinforcing the lower esophageal sphincter.
Treatment: Nissen fundoplication or other surgical techniques.

Explanation: Similar to adult anti-reflux surgery but tailored for pediatric patients.
Symptoms: Vomiting, failure to thrive, respiratory issues.

Explanation: Post-operative care guidance after anti-reflux surgery in children.
Post-operative instructions following anti-reflux surgery in adults.
Toxicity caused by ingestion or inhalation of chemicals found in anti-rust products.
Treatment: Decontamination, supportive care, antidotes if available.
Suggestion: Avoid exposure and seek immediate medical help.

Explanation: Blood test to detect antibodies against smooth muscle, used in diagnosing autoimmune hepatitis.
Suggestion: Important for autoimmune liver disease diagnosis.

Explanation: Condition where bacteria evolve to survive exposure to antibiotics.
Symptoms: Persistent infections not responding to treatment.
Treatment: Use of alternative or combination antibiotics.

Explanation: Proteins produced by immune system to neutralize pathogens.
Causes: Immune response to infection or vaccination.

Explanation: Test measuring concentration of specific antibodies to determine immunity or infection.
Suggestion: Used for vaccine response or diagnosis.

Explanation: Poisoning due to ingestion of rodent poisons that interfere with blood clotting.
Medicines: Vitamin K, blood products if severe.

Explanation: Toxic effects caused by excessive intake of antidiarrheal medications.
Treatment: Supportive care, activated charcoal if early.

Explanation: Test to measure levels of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) for evaluating fluid balance disorders.
Toxicity caused by ingestion of antifreeze substances containing ethylene glycol.
Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, metabolic acidosis, kidney failure.
Treatment: Emergency care, antidotes (fomepizole or ethanol), dialysis.

Explanation: Substances that trigger an immune response by producing antibodies.
Suggestion: Important for vaccines and immune diagnostics.

Explanation: Medications used to block histamine effects and relieve allergy symptoms.
Causes: Allergic reactions to pollen, dust, food, etc.
Treatment: Use of antihistamines orally or topically.

Explanation: Blood test detecting antibodies against mitochondria, used in primary biliary cholangitis diagnosis.
Blood test that detects autoantibodies, commonly used to diagnose autoimmune diseases.
Causes: Suspected lupus, rheumatoid arthritis, or related disorders.

Explanation: Test detecting antibodies against stomach parietal cells to diagnose pernicious anemia or autoimmune gastritis.
Autoimmune disorder causing blood clots due to antiphospholipid antibodies.
Drugs that prevent platelet aggregation to reduce blood clot risk.
Causes: Used in heart attack or stroke prevention.

Explanation: A mental health disorder characterized by disregard for others, impulsivity, and violation of social norms.
Causes: Genetic factors, childhood trauma, environmental influences.
Symptoms: Deceitfulness, irritability, lack of remorse, impulsive behavior.
Treatment: Psychotherapy, behavioral therapy, medications for associated symptoms.
Suggestion: Long-term therapy needed; social support important.

Explanation: Blood test measuring antibodies against streptolysin O, indicating recent streptococcal infection.
Causes: Suspected rheumatic fever or post-streptococcal complications.
Suggestion: Used to confirm past streptococcal infection.

Explanation: Test to measure antithrombin III levels, important for blood clot regulation.
Blood test detecting antibodies against thyroglobulin, used to diagnose autoimmune thyroid disease.
Minimally invasive procedure to repair an aortic aneurysm using a stent graft.
Causes: Aortic aneurysm diagnosed and at risk of rupture.
Symptoms: Often asymptomatic, may have abdominal/back pain.
Suggestion: Less invasive alternative to open surgery.

Explanation: Post-procedure care instructions following endovascular aortic aneurysm repair.
Imaging test to visualize the aorta using contrast dye and X-rays.
Rare condition involving inflammation and narrowing of arteries in the aortic arch.
Symptoms: Arm or neck pain, decreased pulses, dizziness.
Suggestion: Early diagnosis critical to prevent complications.

Explanation: Serious condition where a tear occurs in the aortic wall layers causing blood to flow between layers.
Causes: High blood pressure, connective tissue disorders.
Symptoms: Severe chest/back pain, loss of consciousness.

Explanation: A condition where the aortic valve does not close properly, causing blood to flow backward into the left ventricle.
Causes: Rheumatic fever, congenital valve defects, endocarditis.
Treatment: Medications to reduce workload on heart; valve repair or replacement surgery.
Suggestion: Regular monitoring and follow-up with cardiologist.

Explanation: Narrowing of the aortic valve opening restricting blood flow from the heart.
Causes: Age-related calcification, congenital valve abnormalities, rheumatic fever.
Symptoms: Chest pain, fainting, heart failure symptoms.
Treatment: Valve replacement surgery or balloon valvuloplasty.

Explanation: Surgical procedure to repair or replace the aortic valve using smaller incisions.
Treatment: Minimally invasive valve repair or replacement.
Suggestion: Reduced recovery time compared to open surgery.

Explanation: Traditional open-heart surgery for aortic valve repair or replacement.
Medicines: Post-operative medications for healing and anticoagulation.

Explanation: Rare congenital heart defect with abnormal connection between aorta and pulmonary artery.
Symptoms: Breathlessness, heart failure symptoms in infants.
Suggestion: Early diagnosis and surgery improves outcomes.

Explanation: Genetic disorder causing premature fusion of skull bones and syndactyly (fused fingers/toes).
Symptoms: Abnormal skull shape, fused digits, developmental delays.

Explanation: Scoring system to quickly assess newborn health at 1 and 5 minutes after birth.
Suggestion: Helps determine need for neonatal resuscitation.

Explanation: Condition where bone marrow fails to produce adequate blood cells.
Treatment: Blood transfusions, immunosuppressive therapy, bone marrow transplant.

Explanation: Temporary cessation of breathing in premature infants due to immature brainstem respiratory control.
A protein essential for the metabolism of lipoproteins and cholesterol transport in blood.
Symptoms: Usually asymptomatic; linked to cardiovascular diseases.
Treatment: Focus on managing cholesterol levels and cardiovascular risk.
Suggestion: Regular lipid profile and cardiovascular check-ups.

Explanation: A protein involved in lipid metabolism activating lipoprotein lipase to break down triglycerides.
Sudden neurological impairment due to hemorrhage or stroke.
Symptoms: Sudden weakness, speech difficulty, loss of consciousness.
Treatment: Emergency medical care; depends on cause.

Explanation: Surgical removal of the appendix, usually due to appendicitis.
Symptoms: Right lower abdominal pain, fever, nausea.

Explanation: Inflammation of the appendix, a medical emergency.
Causes: Blockage of appendix lumen by fecalith, infection.
Symptoms: Right lower quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, fever.
Suggestion: Do not delay surgery; risk of rupture.

Explanation: Reduced desire to eat, may be due to illness or psychological factors.
Increased hunger or food intake.
Term used to describe babies whose birth weight is within normal range for their gestational age.
Suggestion: Regular prenatal care to ensure fetal growth.

Explanation: Neurological disorder affecting the ability to perform purposeful movements despite normal muscle function.
Symptoms: Difficulty with motor planning, coordination problems.

Explanation: Condition characterized by abnormally long and slender fingers and toes.
Symptoms: Long fingers, joint laxity, cardiovascular abnormalities.

Disease: Are you getting too much exercise?
Explanation: Concerns related to over-exercising that can lead to physical and mental health issues.
Symptoms: Fatigue, injury, mood changes, poor performance.
Treatment: Rest, modify exercise routine, nutrition support.
Suggestion: Balance exercise and rest; consult trainer or doctor if needed.

Explanation: Imaging test to visualize bones, blood vessels, and tissues of the arm.
Causes: Used for diagnosis of fractures, infections, tumors.

Explanation: Magnetic resonance imaging for detailed visualization of soft tissues in the arm.
Causes: Used to diagnose muscle, ligament, nerve, or vascular injuries.

Explanation: A swelling or mass felt in the underarm area.
Causes: Infections, cysts, lymph node enlargement, or tumors.
Treatment: Depends on cause; antibiotics or surgical removal.
Suggestion: Medical evaluation to rule out serious causes.

Explanation: Irregular heartbeats caused by abnormal electrical signals.
Treatment: Medications, lifestyle changes, procedures like ablation.

Explanation: Sudden blockage of an artery by an embolus (blood clot or other material).
Symptoms: Sudden pain, cold limb, loss of pulse.

Explanation: Poor blood flow through arteries, causing tissue ischemia.
Symptoms: Leg pain on walking, ulcers, cold skin.

Explanation: Procedure to draw blood from an artery for blood gas analysis.
Causes: Used in critical care to assess oxygenation and acid-base status.

Explanation: Imaging test using contrast dye to visualize arteries.
Causes: Used to diagnose vascular diseases or blockages.

Explanation: Inflammation of joints causing pain and stiffness.
Symptoms: Joint pain, swelling, decreased range of motion.

Explanation: Educational material to help manage arthritis.
Suggestion: Utilize patient education and support groups.

Explanation: Implanted device to treat urinary incontinence by controlling urine flow.
Causes: Used after prostate surgery or nerve injury.

Explanation: Chronic lung disease caused by inhalation of asbestos fibers.
Symptoms: Shortness of breath, cough, chest tightness.
Treatment: No cure; symptom management and avoiding exposure.
Suggestion: Avoid asbestos exposure; regular lung monitoring.

Explanation: Parasitic infection caused by roundworm Ascaris lumbricoides.
Accumulation of fluid in the abdominal cavity.
Symptoms: Abdominal swelling, discomfort, shortness of breath.

Explanation: Formation of scar tissue inside the uterus leading to menstrual abnormalities and infertility.
Symptoms: Absent or reduced menstrual flow, infertility.

Explanation: Blood test measuring AST enzyme indicating liver or muscle damage.
A non-essential amino acid important in metabolism and nervous system function.
Infection caused by Aspergillus fungi, affecting lungs primarily.
Suggestion: Avoid exposure; immunocompromised patients at risk.

Explanation: Blood test to detect antibodies against Aspergillus species.
Causes: Used to diagnose allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis.
Suggestion: Diagnostic test for suspected fungal allergy.

Explanation: Toxic effects caused by ingestion or inhalation of asphalt fumes or cement.
Inhalation of food, liquid, or foreign material into the lungs.
Treatment: Clear airway, antibiotics if pneumonia develops.
Suggestion: Avoid eating while unconscious; swallowing therapy.

Explanation: Lung infection caused by inhaling foreign material.
Use of aspirin to prevent heart attacks and strokes.
Suggestion: Consult doctor before starting aspirin therapy.

Explanation: Excessive intake of aspirin leading to toxicity.
Suggestion: Keep medications out of reach of children.

Explanation: Use of forceps to help deliver a baby during labor.
Chronic inflammatory disease of the airways causing wheezing and breathlessness.
Care instructions for children discharged after asthma treatment.
Medications used to prevent asthma attacks.
Medications used for immediate relief during asthma attacks.
Suggestion: Use as needed; seek emergency care if no relief.

Explanation: Educational materials and support for asthma and allergies.
Managing asthma in school-aged children.

Disease: Asthma in adults - what to ask the doctor
Explanation: Guidance on important questions for adult asthma patients.
Chronic airway disease affecting children causing breathing difficulty.

Disease: Asthma in children - what to ask your doctor
Explanation: Questions parents should ask for child's asthma management.
A common eye defect causing blurred vision due to irregular cornea shape.
Condition showing no noticeable symptoms.
Presence of bacteria in urine without symptoms.
Causes: Often in elderly or pregnant women.
Treatment: Usually no treatment unless pregnant or prior to urological procedures.

Explanation: HIV infection without symptoms during early stages.
Rare inherited neurodegenerative disorder causing poor coordination.
Collapse of part or all of a lung leading to reduced gas exchange.
Kidney damage caused by cholesterol emboli blocking small arteries.
Build-up of plaques in arteries leading to narrowed vessels.
Fungal infection of the skin on feet.
Chronic inflammatory skin condition causing itchy rash.
Care instructions for children with atopic dermatitis.
Suggestion: Avoid triggers and maintain skin hydration.

Explanation: Aseptic meningitis is an inflammation of the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord (meninges), not caused by bacterial infection but typically by viruses.
Medicine: Antivirals (like acyclovir if herpes virus suspected)
Suggestion: Usually resolves on its own, but medical evaluation is important to rule out bacterial meningitis.

IsTestDoctorRequired.Tests: Lumbar puncture (spinal tap), MRI, blood tests

Explanation: Aspergillosis is an infection caused by Aspergillus, a common mold that affects the lungs and sinuses and can spread in immunocompromised individuals.
Causes: Lung diseases like asthma or TB
Suggestion: Important for immunocompromised patients to avoid dusty environments.

IsTestDoctorRequired.Tests: Chest X-ray, CT scan, Fungal culture, Blood tests

Explanation: Asthma is a chronic lung condition where airways narrow and swell, producing extra mucus and making breathing difficult.
Suggestion: Avoid allergens, pollution, and cold air. Use inhaler as prescribed.

IsTestDoctorRequired.Tests: Spirometry, Peak flow measurement, Allergy tests

Explanation: Astigmatism is an imperfection in the curvature of the eye’s cornea or lens, leading to distorted or blurred vision.
Medicine: None needed; optical correction or surgery is used
Suggestion: Routine eye exams help detect and manage astigmatism early.

Explanation: Presence of bacteria in urine without symptoms of urinary tract infection (UTI); common in elderly and pregnant women.
Treatment: Not treated unless pregnant or undergoing urologic procedure
Suggestion: Pregnant women should be screened and treated. Others typically don’t need antibiotics.

Explanation: Atherosclerosis is the buildup of fats, cholesterol, and plaque on artery walls, leading to restricted blood flow.
Suggestion: Maintain healthy weight, quit smoking, and manage diabetes.

IsTestDoctorRequired.Tests: Lipid profile, ECG, Angiography, Stress test

Explanation: A fungal infection that usually begins between the toes and causes itching, stinging, and burning.
Suggestion: Maintain good foot hygiene and avoid walking barefoot in public areas.

IsTestDoctorRequired.Tests: Skin scraping or culture (only if diagnosis unclear)

Description: A hearing disorder where sound enters the inner ear normally but the transmission of signals from the inner ear to the brain is impaired.
Medications: No specific drugs; cochlear implants often used
CoverageAdvice: Covered under ENT and audiology-related insurance with special hearing aid or implant coverage.

Description: Non-cancerous growths in the ear canal often associated with chronic infections or inflammation.
Causes: Irritation or trauma to the ear
CoverageAdvice: May be covered under ENT outpatient procedures.

Description: Abnormal sounds heard via stethoscope indicating underlying lung, heart, or gastrointestinal conditions.
CoverageAdvice: Test itself covered under standard consultation; follow-up may depend on diagnosis.

Description: A condition where the immune system attacks the brain, causing inflammation and neurological dysfunction.
CoverageAdvice: Generally covered under neurological or critical illness coverage if hospitalization is needed.

Description: A chronic disease in which the immune system attacks liver cells, leading to inflammation and damage.
CoverageAdvice: Covered under liver or autoimmune treatment sections of insurance.

Description: An autoimmune condition that affects the inner ear, leading to hearing loss and balance issues.
Causes: Immune system attack on inner ear proteins
CoverageAdvice: Partial coverage for medications and hearing devices under ENT

Description: A form of chronic pancreatitis caused by immune-mediated inflammation.
CoverageAdvice: Covered under critical care or GI-related hospitalizations.

Description: A sudden onset of high blood pressure in people with spinal cord injuries.
CoverageAdvice: Covered under neurological emergency care.

Description: A genetic disorder characterized by the growth of numerous cysts in the kidneys.
Remedies: Dialysis or transplant in advanced stages
CoverageAdvice: Partially covered under chronic kidney disease or dialysis plans.

Description: A rarer form of PKD occurring in infants and children, causing enlarged kidneys and liver fibrosis.
CoverageAdvice: Typically covered under neonatal intensive care or pediatric genetic disorders.

Description: An abnormal connection between an artery and a vein, bypassing capillaries. Can be congenital or acquired.
Remedies: Observation for small fistulas; surgery or embolization for large ones.
Advice: Consult if you notice swelling or abnormal pulsing under skin.

Description: Arthralgia is joint pain without inflammation. It can be acute or chronic and may affect one or multiple joints.
Remedies: Rest, ice packs, gentle stretching, and physiotherapy.
Advice: Avoid strenuous activity and seek evaluation if persistent.

TestAndAppointment.Tests: X-ray, blood tests (ESR, CRP), Rheumatoid factor

Description: Inflammation of one or more joints, leading to pain, swelling, and reduced range of motion. Common types include osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis.
Remedies: Physical therapy, joint protection techniques, and weight management.
Advice: Early treatment improves long-term joint function.

TestAndAppointment.Tests: X-rays, MRI, blood tests (RA factor, CRP, ESR)

Description: An intestinal infection caused by the Ascaris lumbricoides roundworm. It's one of the most common parasitic infections.
Causes: Consumption of contaminated food or water
Remedies: Good hygiene, improved sanitation, deworming programs
Advice: Wash hands and cook food properly to avoid reinfection.

TestAndAppointment.Tests: Stool test for ova and parasites

Description: A fungal infection caused by Aspergillus species. Can be allergic, invasive, or chronic.
Causes: Inhalation of Aspergillus spores in immunocompromised individuals
Remedies: Avoid moldy environments, use air purifiers
Advice: Seek care if you're immunocompromised and develop chest symptoms.

TestAndAppointment.Tests: CT scan, Sputum culture, Blood tests for fungal markers

Description: A common condition affecting the lower, middle, or upper back, usually caused by strain, injury, or underlying conditions.
Symptoms: Dull or sharp pain in the back
Remedies: Physical therapy, heat/cold packs, posture correction.
Advice: Maintain proper posture, use ergonomic furniture, and stay physically active.

Description: A serious infection of the membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord caused by bacteria.
Advice: Vaccination and early treatment are crucial.

TestAndAppointment.Tests: Lumbar puncture, blood culture, CT scan

Description: A mild infection of the vagina caused by bacteria.
Advice: Use protection during intercourse and complete the full antibiotic course.

Description: A condition in which the esophageal lining changes due to long-term acid reflux.
Remedies: Lifestyle changes, acid suppression therapy, and monitoring.
Advice: Elevate head while sleeping, avoid acidic/spicy foods, regular monitoring.

Description: A type of skin cancer that begins in the basal cells — usually from sun exposure.
Advice: Use sunscreen and wear protective clothing outdoors.

Description: Sudden weakness or paralysis of facial muscles, typically on one side.
Advice: Start treatment within 72 hours of symptom onset for best recovery.

Description: Enlargement of the prostate gland, common in older men.
Remedies: Lifestyle changes, medication, or surgery if needed.
Advice: Limit caffeine/alcohol and avoid late fluid intake.

TestAndAppointment.Tests: PSA blood test, ultrasound, urine flow study

Description: A disease caused by a deficiency of vitamin B1 (thiamine).
Advice: Include whole grains, legumes, and meat in diet.

Description: A liver disease in infants where bile ducts are blocked or absent.
Remedies: Surgery (Kasai procedure), liver transplant in severe cases.

Description: A mental condition marked by alternating periods of elation and depression.
Remedies: Long-term therapy, medication management, regular monitoring.
Advice: Regular sleep and avoiding triggers are essential.

Description: An acute inflammation of the membranes (meninges) surrounding the brain and spinal cord, caused by bacterial infection.
Remedies: Immediate hospitalization, IV antibiotics, supportive care.
Advice: Seek emergency care at the onset of symptoms.

TestAndAppointment.Tests: Lumbar puncture (CSF analysis), Blood cultures, CT scan

Description: A mild infection of the vagina caused by an imbalance of naturally occurring bacterial flora.
Symptoms: Thin white or gray vaginal discharge
Remedies: Avoid douching and scented products, maintain vaginal hygiene.
Advice: Complete the full course of antibiotics.

Description: A condition where the esophageal lining changes due to long-term acid reflux, increasing cancer risk.
Remedies: Diet changes, manage acid reflux, regular monitoring.
Advice: Endoscopic monitoring is crucial to detect progression to cancer.

Description: The most common type of skin cancer arising from basal cells in the epidermis.
Remedies: Early removal, sun protection, routine skin checks.
Medications: Fluorouracil cream (in early cases), targeted therapy in advanced stages
Advice: See a dermatologist for skin lesion evaluation.

Description: Sudden, temporary weakness or paralysis of the facial muscles on one side due to facial nerve inflammation.
Advice: Most cases resolve within weeks, seek treatment early.

Explanation: A serious infection of the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord.
Causes: Bacterial infection (e.g., Neisseria meningitidis, Streptococcus pneumoniae)
Symptoms: Fever, headache, neck stiffness, photophobia, confusion.

Explanation: A common vaginal infection caused by an imbalance of bacteria.
Causes: Overgrowth of certain bacteria in the vagina.
Symptoms: Thin, gray vaginal discharge, fishy odor, itching.
Suggestion: Complete the full course of antibiotics.

Explanation: A condition where the esophagus lining changes, increasing cancer risk.
Symptoms: Often asymptomatic; may have heartburn, difficulty swallowing.
Treatment: Medications, endoscopic surveillance, surgery in severe cases.

Explanation: The most common type of skin cancer, usually slow-growing.
Symptoms: Pearly or waxy bump, flat flesh-colored lesion.

Explanation: Sudden weakness or paralysis of facial muscles, usually temporary.
Symptoms: Facial droop, inability to close eye, drooling.

Explanation: Non-cancerous enlargement of the prostate gland in men.
Symptoms: Frequent urination, weak stream, difficulty starting urination.

Explanation: A disease caused by vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency.
Suggestion: Improve diet and treat underlying causes.

Explanation: A genetic blood disorder causing reduced hemoglobin production.
Treatment: Blood transfusions, iron chelation, bone marrow transplant.

Explanation: A rare liver disorder in infants where bile ducts are blocked or absent.
Symptoms: Jaundice, dark urine, pale stools, poor weight gain.

Explanation: A mental health condition causing extreme mood swings.
Symptoms: Manic episodes, depressive episodes, mood instability.

Explanation: A malignant tumor in the urinary bladder.
Causes: Smoking, chemical exposure, chronic bladder inflammation.
Symptoms: Blood in urine, frequent urination, pelvic pain.

Explanation: Inflammation of the eyelids causing redness and irritation.
Causes: Bacterial infection, skin conditions (e.g., seborrheic dermatitis).
Symptoms: Red, swollen eyelids, crusting, burning sensation.

Explanation: A blood clot in a deep vein, usually in the legs.
Painful, pus-filled bumps under the skin caused by infected hair follicles.
Symptoms: Red, swollen, tender lump with pus.
Suggestion: Do not squeeze; seek care if severe.

Explanation: A malignant tumor of the bone, such as osteosarcoma or Ewing's sarcoma.
A rare but serious illness caused by a toxin that attacks the body's nerves.
Symptoms: Double vision, drooping eyelids, difficulty swallowing, paralysis.

Explanation: Abnormally slow heart rate (<60 bpm).
Treatment: Treat underlying cause, pacemaker if severe.
Suggestion: Monitor symptoms and seek care if severe.

Explanation: An abnormal growth of cells in the brain, can be benign or malignant.
Suggestion: Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial.

Explanation: A malignant tumor that develops from breast cells.
Symptoms: Lump in breast, nipple discharge, skin changes.

Explanation: A chronic inflammatory disease of the airways causing breathing difficulty.
Symptoms: Wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, cough.
Suggestion: Adhere to treatment plan and avoid triggers.

Explanation: Permanent enlargement of parts of the airways of the lung.
Causes: Chronic infections, cystic fibrosis, immune disorders.
Symptoms: Chronic cough, sputum production, recurrent infections.

Explanation: A bacterial infection from animals, often through unpasteurized dairy.
Suggestion: Avoid unpasteurized dairy and contact with infected animals.

Explanation: An eating disorder marked by binge eating followed by purging.
Symptoms: Binge eating, vomiting, excessive exercise, dental erosion.
Suggestion: Seek help from mental health professionals.

Explanation: Inflammation of the bursae (fluid-filled sacs) near joints.
Suggestion: Avoid repetitive activities and rest the joint.

Explanation: Infection of the heart's inner lining or valves.
Symptoms: Fever, heart murmur, fatigue, night sweats.

Explanation: Lung infection caused by bacteria.
Symptoms: Cough, fever, chest pain, shortness of breath.
Suggestion: Complete the full course of antibiotics.

Explanation: An autoimmune disorder where ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine.
A group of disorders affecting movement and muscle tone, caused by brain damage before or at birth.
Causes: Brain injury, premature birth, infections during pregnancy.

Explanation: A highly contagious viral infection causing an itchy, blister-like rash.
A viral disease transmitted by mosquitoes, causing fever and joint pain.
A common sexually transmitted infection caused by bacteria.
Suggestion: Screening and partner treatment are important.

Explanation: An acute diarrheal illness caused by infection of the intestine.
Suggestion: Safe water and sanitation are key.

Explanation: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue not improved by rest.
Causes: Unknown; possible viral, immune, or psychological factors.
Symptoms: Severe fatigue, sleep problems, joint pain.
