Explanation: Gradual loss of kidney function over time.
A group of lung diseases that block airflow and make breathing difficult.
Long-standing inflammation of the pancreas that alters its normal structure and functions.
Long-term inflammation of the sinuses.
Scarring of the liver due to long-term damage.
Causes: Alcohol abuse, hepatitis B/C, fatty liver.
Suggestion: Avoid alcohol and monitor liver function.

Explanation: A bacterial infection causing severe diarrhea and colitis.
Treatment: Stop offending antibiotics, specific antibiotics for C. diff.
Suggestion: Hand hygiene and infection control are key.

Explanation: Severe headaches on one side of the head, often around the eye.

Tests.Name: Clinical diagnosis, MRI (to rule out other causes)

Explanation: An autoimmune disorder where gluten ingestion damages the small intestine.
A malignant tumor of the colon.
Causes: Genetic factors, polyps, inflammatory bowel disease.
Symptoms: Blood in stool, weight loss, abdominal pain.

Explanation: A viral infection of the upper respiratory tract.
Symptoms: Runny nose, sore throat, cough, sneezing.

Explanation: A condition where the heart cannot pump blood effectively.
Inflammation of the conjunctiva (pink eye).
Infrequent or difficult bowel movements.
Skin inflammation caused by contact with irritants or allergens.
Narrowing or blockage of the coronary arteries.
Symptoms: Chest pain, shortness of breath, fatigue.
Suggestion: Control risk factors and follow up regularly.

Explanation: A reflex action to clear the airways of mucus or irritants.
Symptoms: Dry or productive cough, throat irritation.
Treatment: Depends on cause; cough suppressants, antibiotics if bacterial.

Explanation: A chronic inflammatory bowel disease affecting the digestive tract.
A viral infection causing swelling of the airways in children.
Suggestion: Seek care if breathing difficulty is severe.

Explanation: A fungal infection of the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord.
A hormonal disorder caused by high levels of cortisol.
Symptoms: Weight gain, round face, high blood pressure.
Treatment: Reduce steroid use, surgery for tumors.

Explanation: A genetic disorder affecting the lungs and digestive system.
Symptoms: Chronic cough, lung infections, poor growth.

Explanation: A common scalp condition causing flaking and mild itchiness.
Causes: Dry skin, seborrheic dermatitis, sensitivity to hair products, Malassezia fungus.
Symptoms: White flakes on scalp and hair, itching.
Medicines: Ketoconazole shampoo, selenium sulfide, zinc pyrithione.
Suggestion: Regular hair washing and scalp care.

Explanation: A mosquito-borne viral infection causing flu-like illness and, occasionally, severe complications.
Symptoms: High fever, headache, pain behind eyes, joint and muscle pain, rash.
Suggestion: Prevent mosquito bites and seek care if symptoms worsen.

Explanation: A common mental health disorder characterized by persistent sadness and loss of interest.
Symptoms: Low mood, loss of interest, fatigue, sleep changes, appetite changes.
Suggestion: Seek help from a mental health professional.

Explanation: A chronic condition where the pancreas produces little or no insulin.
Symptoms: Increased thirst, frequent urination, weight loss, fatigue.
Treatment: Insulin therapy, blood sugar monitoring, diet management.
Suggestion: Lifelong insulin and regular monitoring required.

Explanation: A chronic condition affecting the way the body processes blood sugar (glucose).
Causes: Insulin resistance, obesity, genetics, lifestyle factors.
Symptoms: Increased thirst, frequent urination, fatigue, blurred vision.

Explanation: A diabetes complication that affects eyes, caused by damage to blood vessels of the retina.
Causes: Chronic high blood sugar in diabetes.
Treatment: Blood sugar control, laser therapy, injections.

Explanation: Frequent, loose, or watery bowel movements.
Causes: Infections, food intolerance, medications, chronic diseases.
Suggestion: Maintain hydration and seek care if severe.

Explanation: A serious bacterial infection affecting the mucous membranes of the throat and nose.
Symptoms: Sore throat, fever, swollen glands, thick gray membrane in throat.

Explanation: Inflammation or infection of small pouches (diverticula) in the digestive tract.
Symptoms: Abdominal pain, fever, nausea, change in bowel habits.
Suggestion: Increase dietary fiber and follow up regularly.

Explanation: A genetic disorder caused by the presence of an extra chromosome 21.
Symptoms: Intellectual disability, characteristic facial features, heart defects.
Treatment: Supportive care, early intervention, special education.
Suggestion: Early intervention improves quality of life.

Explanation: Inflammation of the skin causing redness, swelling, and itching.
Symptoms: Red, itchy, swollen skin, sometimes with blisters.

Explanation: A blood clot in a deep vein, usually in the legs.
A condition that occurs when the body loses more fluids than it takes in.
Causes: Vomiting, diarrhea, excessive sweating, inadequate intake.
Symptoms: Thirst, dry mouth, dark urine, dizziness.
Suggestion: Drink fluids regularly, especially in hot weather or illness.

Explanation: A sudden change in mental status causing confusion and reduced awareness.
Suggestion: Monitor for safety and seek medical evaluation.

Explanation: A group of symptoms affecting memory, thinking, and social abilities.
Causes: Alzheimer's disease, vascular disease, Lewy body disease.
Suggestion: Early diagnosis and support are important.

Explanation: Decay of teeth due to bacterial activity.
Causes: Poor oral hygiene, sugary diet, bacteria.
Suggestion: Brush and floss regularly, visit dentist.

Explanation: A rare inflammatory disease causing muscle weakness and skin rash.
Symptoms: Muscle weakness, skin rash, difficulty swallowing.

Explanation: A fungal infection of the skin, hair, or nails.
Symptoms: Red, itchy, circular rash with clear center.
Suggestion: Maintain hygiene and avoid sharing personal items.

Explanation: A rare, noncancerous growth arising from connective tissue.
Symptoms: Painless or painful mass, restricted movement.

Explanation: A condition where the hip joint does not develop properly in infants and children.
Causes: Genetic factors, breech birth, family history.
Symptoms: Uneven leg lengths, limited hip movement, limping.
Suggestion: Early detection and treatment are crucial.

Explanation: A serious diabetes complication where the body produces excess blood acids (ketones).
Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, rapid breathing, confusion.

Explanation: A common form of inflamed skin that appears as a patchwork of bright red skin on your baby's bottom.
Causes: Prolonged exposure to wet or dirty diapers, friction, yeast infection.
Symptoms: Red, tender skin in diaper area.
Medicines: Zinc oxide cream, antifungal cream (if needed).

Explanation: A chronic skin condition of sores with inflammation and scarring favoring the face, ears, and scalp.
Symptoms: Red, scaly patches, hair loss, scarring.

Explanation: An injury where a joint is forced out of normal position.
Symptoms: Pain, swelling, deformity, inability to move joint.

Explanation: A serious disorder in which the proteins that control blood clotting become overactive.
Symptoms: Bleeding, bruising, low blood pressure, organ failure.
Treatment: Treat underlying cause, blood products, supportive care.

Explanation: A mental health condition characterized by the presence of two or more distinct personality states.
Causes: Severe trauma during early childhood, usually extreme, repetitive physical, sexual, or emotional abuse.
Symptoms: Memory gaps, multiple identities, mood swings.

Explanation: Formation of small pouches (diverticula) in the colon wall.
Symptoms: Often asymptomatic; may cause mild cramps, bloating.

Explanation: An abnormal reaction of the immune system to a medication.
Treatment: Discontinue drug, antihistamines, steroids, epinephrine (if severe).

Explanation: A genetic disorder characterized by progressive muscle degeneration and weakness.
Causes: Mutation in the DMD gene (X-linked recessive).
Symptoms: Muscle weakness, difficulty walking, frequent falls.

Explanation: A sore that develops on the lining of the duodenum (first part of the small intestine).
Suggestion: Complete the full course of antibiotics if prescribed.

Explanation: A learning disorder characterized by difficulty reading.
Painful menstruation, typically involving abdominal cramps.
Symptoms: Lower abdominal pain, back pain, nausea.

Explanation: A condition of impaired digestion causing discomfort in the upper abdomen.
Symptoms: Bloating, nausea, burping, upper abdominal pain.
Treatment: Dietary changes, antacids, treat underlying cause.
Suggestion: Eat smaller meals and avoid trigger foods.

Explanation: A movement disorder in which muscles contract uncontrollably.
Treatment: Botulinum toxin injections, physical therapy, medications.

Explanation: Infection and inflammation of the tear (lacrimal) sac.
Causes: Blockage of the nasolacrimal duct, bacterial infection.
Symptoms: Pain, redness, swelling near the inner corner of the eye, discharge.
Treatment: Antibiotics, warm compresses, surgery if chronic.
Suggestion: Seek prompt treatment to avoid complications.

Explanation: Partial or complete loss of hearing.
Causes: Genetic factors, infections, trauma, aging, noise exposure.
Symptoms: Difficulty hearing, asking for repetition, social withdrawal.
Treatment: Hearing aids, cochlear implants, sign language.

Explanation: A condition caused by dissolved gases coming out of solution into bubbles inside the body on depressurization.
Causes: Rapid ascent from deep water diving, unpressurized air travel.
Treatment: Recompression in a hyperbaric chamber, oxygen therapy.
Suggestion: Ascend slowly when diving; seek emergency care if symptoms occur.

Explanation: Serious infection in the deep spaces of the neck, potentially life-threatening.
Symptoms: Neck swelling, pain, fever, difficulty swallowing.

Explanation: Age-related changes in spinal discs causing pain and reduced mobility.
Symptoms: Back pain, neck pain, numbness, weakness.

Explanation: A severe, often fatal illness in humans caused by the Ebola virus.
Causes: Ebola virus infection (contact with infected body fluids).
Symptoms: Fever, severe headache, muscle pain, vomiting, diarrhea, bleeding.
Suggestion: Strict infection control and isolation required.

Explanation: A chronic skin condition causing itchy, inflamed skin.
Causes: Genetic predisposition, environmental triggers, immune dysfunction.
Suggestion: Avoid triggers and keep skin moisturized.

Explanation: A serious complication of pregnancy characterized by seizures.
Causes: Severe preeclampsia (high blood pressure in pregnancy).
Symptoms: Seizures, high blood pressure, swelling, headache.
Treatment: Magnesium sulfate, antihypertensives, delivery of baby.

Tests.Name: Blood pressure, urine protein, blood tests

Explanation: A pregnancy that occurs outside the uterus, usually in a fallopian tube.
Causes: Tubal damage, previous ectopic pregnancy, infections.

Explanation: Swelling caused by excess fluid trapped in the body's tissues.
Causes: Heart failure, kidney disease, liver disease, medications.
Symptoms: Swelling in legs, feet, hands, or other areas.

Explanation: A group of inherited disorders affecting connective tissues, causing hypermobility and fragile skin.
Symptoms: Joint hypermobility, stretchy skin, easy bruising.
Treatment: Physical therapy, pain management, protective measures.
Suggestion: Genetic counseling and regular monitoring recommended.

Explanation: A long-term complication of uncorrected congenital heart defects causing pulmonary hypertension.
Causes: Unrepaired heart defects (e.g., VSD, ASD, PDA).
Symptoms: Cyanosis, shortness of breath, fatigue, clubbing of fingers.
Suggestion: Early correction of heart defects prevents syndrome.

Explanation: Obstruction of a blood vessel by a clot or foreign material.
Causes: Blood clots, fat, air, amniotic fluid.
Symptoms: Sudden pain, swelling, shortness of breath (if pulmonary).
Suggestion: Seek immediate medical attention if suspected.

Explanation: A type of COPD involving damage to the air sacs in the lungs.
Symptoms: Shortness of breath, chronic cough, wheezing.
Suggestion: Quit smoking and avoid lung irritants.

Explanation: Inflammation of the brain, usually due to viral infection.
Suggestion: Seek urgent care for neurological symptoms.

Explanation: A rare genetic disorder resulting from the buildup of a particular type of fat, leading to pain and organ dysfunction.
Causes: Mutation in the GLA gene (X-linked recessive).
Symptoms: Pain in hands and feet, skin rash, kidney and heart problems.
Suggestion: Genetic counseling and regular monitoring recommended.

Explanation: Loss of facial movement due to nerve damage.
Symptoms: Drooping of one side of the face, inability to close eye, drooling.

Explanation: A genetic disorder that increases the risk of developing abnormal blood clots.
Suggestion: Genetic counseling and regular monitoring recommended.

Explanation: A genetic disorder characterized by high cholesterol levels, increasing heart disease risk.
Causes: Mutations in LDLR, APOB, or PCSK9 genes.
Symptoms: High cholesterol, xanthomas, early heart disease.
Suggestion: Family screening and early intervention are important.

Explanation: A rare inherited blood disorder leading to bone marrow failure.
Causes: Mutations in genes involved in DNA repair.
Symptoms: Fatigue, frequent infections, easy bruising, skeletal abnormalities.
Suggestion: Genetic counseling and regular monitoring recommended.

Explanation: Hardened deposits in the gallbladder that can block bile flow.
Suggestion: Avoid fatty foods; regular checkups if symptomatic.

Explanation: Tissue death due to lack of blood supply or infection.
Suggestion: Early intervention is crucial to prevent spread.

Explanation: Inflammation of the stomach lining.
Causes: H. pylori infection, NSAIDs, alcohol, stress.
Treatment: Diet modification, antacids, antibiotics (if H. pylori).
Suggestion: Avoid irritants; test for H. pylori if recurrent.

Explanation: A chronic condition where stomach acid flows into the esophagus.
Causes: Weak lower esophageal sphincter, obesity, smoking.
Suggestion: Avoid late meals and spicy foods.

Explanation: Inflammation of the stomach and intestines caused by infection.
Suggestion: Stay hydrated and avoid contaminated food.

Explanation: A rare genetic disorder where fat accumulates in cells and organs.
Causes: Mutation in GBA gene affecting enzyme glucocerebrosidase.

Explanation: A mental health disorder characterized by excessive, chronic worry.
Suggestion: Stress management and psychotherapy are key.

Explanation: A sexually transmitted infection causing painful sores on genitals.
Symptoms: Painful blisters, itching, burning while urinating.
Suggestion: Safe sex practices and regular STI checkups.

Explanation: Small growths caused by certain strains of HPV on genital areas.
Symptoms: Flesh-colored or gray warts around genitals or anus.
Suggestion: HPV vaccination and safe sex recommended.

Explanation: Inflammation of the arteries, usually in the head.
Causes: Unknown, but linked to immune dysfunction and age.

Explanation: Parasitic infection of the intestines caused by Giardia.
Symptoms: Diarrhea, greasy stools, weight loss, bloating.
Suggestion: Ensure clean drinking water and proper sanitation.

Explanation: A harmless liver condition causing increased bilirubin levels.
A condition that damages the optic nerve due to high eye pressure.
Symptoms: Loss of peripheral vision, eye pain (acute angle).
Suggestion: Regular eye exams are key to early detection.

Explanation: Inflammation of the kidney's filtering units (glomeruli).
Symptoms: Blood in urine, swelling, high BP, reduced kidney function.
Suggestion: Early intervention can prevent kidney damage.

Explanation: Inflammation of the tongue causing pain and swelling.
Symptoms: Swollen, red, smooth tongue, burning sensation.

Explanation: Enlargement of the thyroid gland.
Suggestion: Thyroid function test should be done.

Explanation: A common bacterial STD affecting genitals, rectum, throat.
Causes: Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection via sexual contact.
Suggestion: Screening recommended for sexually active individuals.

Explanation: A type of arthritis due to uric acid crystal deposition in joints.
Causes: Excess uric acid from diet, alcohol, kidney issues.
Symptoms: Sudden joint pain, redness, swelling (esp. big toe).
Suggestion: Avoid red meat, alcohol, high-purine foods.

Tests.Name: Uric acid test, joint fluid test

Explanation: A rare autoimmune disease causing inflammation of blood vessels (vasculitis).
Symptoms: Nosebleeds, sinus infections, kidney dysfunction, fatigue.

Explanation: A rare neurological disorder where the immune system attacks peripheral nerves.
Symptoms: Weakness, tingling, paralysis starting from legs upward.

Explanation: Bleeding in the digestive tract, can be mild to severe.
Symptoms: Blood in stool/vomit, black stool, weakness.

Explanation: Inflammation of the gums, often due to plaque buildup.
A genetic disorder causing red blood cells to break down under stress.
Symptoms: Jaundice, fatigue, dark urine after infection or certain drugs.
Treatment: Avoid triggers, supportive care during episodes.

Explanation: A skin condition with ring-shaped, reddish bumps.
Causes: Unknown, possibly autoimmune or due to diabetes.
Symptoms: Ring-shaped skin lesions, mostly on hands/feet.
Suggestion: Usually self-limiting; no treatment needed in mild cases.

Explanation: A rare type of tumor in the GI tract arising from interstitial cells of Cajal.
Causes: Mutations in KIT or PDGFRA genes.
Symptoms: Bleeding, abdominal pain, bloating, weight loss.

Explanation: Inflammatory arthritis due to urate crystal buildup in joints.
Causes: Hyperuricemia from kidney dysfunction or diet.

Tests.Name: Serum uric acid, synovial fluid analysis

Explanation: Inadequate secretion of growth hormone from the pituitary gland.
Symptoms: Short stature in children, fatigue, poor muscle mass.

Explanation: Enlargement of male breast tissue.
A rare inherited disorder affecting kidney function, leading to low potassium and magnesium.
Symptoms: Fatigue, muscle cramps, salt craving, low BP.

Explanation: Cancer originating in the lining of the stomach.
Causes: H. pylori infection, smoking, diet, genetics.
Symptoms: Weight loss, abdominal pain, nausea, black stools.
Suggestion: Early screening in high-risk individuals recommended.

Explanation: Tuberculosis infection affecting reproductive organs.
Suggestion: Rule out in infertility cases in endemic areas.

Explanation: An autoimmune condition causing hyperthyroidism.
Symptoms: Weight loss, anxiety, heat intolerance, bulging eyes.
Suggestion: Regular thyroid function monitoring is essential.

Explanation: A feeling of a lump in the throat with no actual obstruction.
Causes: Stress, GERD, muscle tension, postnasal drip.
Symptoms: Sensation of a foreign body in throat.
Suggestion: Psychological factors often play a role.

Description: Open sores that develop on the stomach lining due to acid erosion.
Symptoms: Stomach pain, bloating, heartburn, nausea, vomiting blood.
Causes: H. pylori infection, NSAID use, smoking, alcohol.
Remedies: Avoid spicy food, stop NSAIDs, lifestyle changes.
Medications: Proton pump inhibitors (omeprazole), antacids, antibiotics for H. pylori.
Advice: Seek medical care if symptoms persist or bleeding occurs.
IsTestOrDoctorRequired: Yes. Endoscopy and H. pylori test. ₹2,000–₹5,000.

Description: Bleeding occurring anywhere in the gastrointestinal tract.
Symptoms: Black or bloody stool, vomiting blood, fatigue, low BP.
Remedies: Treat underlying cause, blood transfusion if severe.
Medications: PPI, octreotide (for varices), antibiotics if infection.
IsTestOrDoctorRequired: Yes. Endoscopy, stool test, CT scan. ₹3,000–₹8,000.

Description: Rare tumor in the digestive tract, often in the stomach or small intestine.
IsTestOrDoctorRequired: Yes. CT scan, biopsy, PET scan. ₹10,000–₹30,000.

Description: Viral rash commonly affecting young children.
Symptoms: Symmetrical red bumps on cheeks, arms, legs, and buttocks.
Causes: Hepatitis B virus, EBV, other viral infections.
Coverage Advice: Basic care, outpatient consult may not be covered.
Advice: Usually resolves in 2–8 weeks. Monitor for fever.

Description: A mild liver disorder where bilirubin levels are slightly elevated.
Symptoms: Mild jaundice, especially during stress or fasting.
Coverage Advice: Usually not covered unless symptoms lead to tests.

Description: Group of eye diseases that damage the optic nerve due to high intraocular pressure.
Symptoms: Blurred vision, eye pain, halos around lights, vision loss.
Coverage Advice: Partially covered; surgery may need approval.

Description: Inflammation of the tongue leading to redness and swelling.
Symptoms: Red, smooth, swollen tongue; pain or burning sensation.
Coverage Advice: Usually not covered unless part of systemic issue.
Advice: Maintain oral hygiene, avoid spicy foods.

Description: Inflammation of the glomeruli in kidneys affecting filtration.
Symptoms: Blood in urine, swelling, high BP, fatigue.
Remedies: Control BP, treat cause, dialysis if severe.
Coverage Advice: Usually covered if hospitalized or part of CKD.

Description: A form of arthritis caused by uric acid crystal buildup in joints.
Symptoms: Sudden joint pain, redness, swelling (often in the big toe).
Causes: High uric acid, purine-rich diet, alcohol, kidney issues.
Coverage Advice: Chronic management may not be covered unless acute attack.
Advice: Dietary control is key to prevention.
IsTestOrDoctorRequired: Yes. Uric acid test, joint aspiration. ₹1,000–₹2,000.

Description: Autoimmune disorder where the immune system attacks the peripheral nerves.
Advice: Seek emergency care if paralysis or breathing issues.
IsTestOrDoctorRequired: Yes. Nerve conduction study, lumbar puncture. ₹10,000–₹25,000.

Description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormone.
Symptoms: Fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, dry skin, constipation.
Causes: Autoimmune disease (Hashimoto's), iodine deficiency, certain medications.
Coverage Advice: Usually covered under general health insurance and endocrine care plans.
Advice: Regular TSH testing, lifelong medication adherence.
IsTestOrDoctorRequired: Yes. TSH and T4 blood tests recommended.

Description: A condition in which the thyroid gland overproduces hormones.
Symptoms: Weight loss, irritability, tremors, palpitations, heat intolerance.
Causes: Graves’ disease, thyroid nodules, excess iodine intake.
Coverage Advice: Covered under hormone disorder or chronic illness plans.
IsTestOrDoctorRequired: Yes. Requires thyroid function tests and imaging.

Description: A rare disorder in which blood doesn't clot normally due to lack of clotting factors.
Symptoms: Excessive bleeding, easy bruising, joint pain due to internal bleeding.
Coverage Advice: Usually covered under rare disease or hematology policies.
Advice: Lifelong care; avoid aspirin and NSAIDs.
IsTestOrDoctorRequired: Yes. Clotting factor tests and genetic screening needed.

Description: A viral liver infection caused by the hepatitis A virus (HAV).
Coverage Advice: Vaccination and outpatient care usually covered.
IsTestOrDoctorRequired: Yes. Liver function tests and anti-HAV antibody tests.

Description: A serious liver infection caused by the hepatitis B virus (HBV).
Symptoms: Fatigue, jaundice, joint pain, dark urine.
Coverage Advice: Antiviral treatment is covered under infectious disease plans.
Advice: Vaccination critical; monitor liver enzymes regularly.
IsTestOrDoctorRequired: Yes. HBsAg and HBV DNA tests.

Description: A liver disease caused by the hepatitis C virus, often chronic.
Coverage Advice: Antiviral treatment may be covered under chronic disease plans.
IsTestOrDoctorRequired: Yes. HCV RNA test and liver function profile.

Description: Spinal disc slips out of place and presses on nearby nerves.
Symptoms: Back pain, numbness, tingling, weakness in limbs.
Remedies: Physical therapy, posture correction, hot/cold therapy.
Coverage Advice: May be covered under orthopedic plans; surgery often covered.
Advice: Avoid lifting heavy objects; regular exercise.
IsTestOrDoctorRequired: Yes. MRI or CT scan required.

Description: Part of the stomach pushes up into the chest through the diaphragm.
Remedies: Elevating head during sleep, small meals.
Advice: Weight management helps; avoid heavy meals.

Description: Red, itchy welts on the skin due to allergic reaction.
Symptoms: Itchy, red, raised rash or welts.
Coverage Advice: Dermatologist visits covered; OTC drugs may not be.
Advice: Avoid known allergens; keep skin moisturized.

Description: A type of cancer originating in the lymphatic system.
Symptoms: Swollen lymph nodes, fever, night sweats, weight loss.
Coverage Advice: Usually covered under cancer care insurance.
Advice: Early diagnosis increases cure rates significantly.
IsTestOrDoctorRequired: Yes. Biopsy and PET/CT scans required.

Causes: Mutations in NF1 or NF2 genes.

Description: Advanced syphilis infection affecting the nervous system.
Serious intestinal disease in premature infants causing tissue death.
Symptoms: Feeding intolerance, abdominal distension, bloody stools.

Description: Bladder dysfunction due to nervous system injury.

Description: Kidney disorder characterized by inflammation of glomeruli.
Damage to nervous tissue by toxins.
Cancer arising from immature nerve cells, mostly in children.
Life-threatening reaction to antipsychotic drugs.
Birth defects of the brain and spinal cord.

Description: Noncancerous growths in nasal passages or sinuses.
Severe inflammation of the pancreas with tissue death.
Degenerative joint disease causing cartilage breakdown.

Description: Condition characterized by decreased bone density and fragility.
Remedies: Calcium and vitamin D supplementation, exercise.
Coverage Advice: Covered under metabolic bone disease care.
Advice: Fall prevention and bone health monitoring.

Description: Infection or inflammation of the middle ear.
Advice: Avoid water in ears and follow up for hearing.

Description: Repeated episodes of partial or complete airway obstruction during sleep.
Advice: Lifestyle modification and adherence to therapy.

Description: Fluid-filled sacs on or inside an ovary.
Infection of the bone and bone marrow.
Inflammation or infection of the outer ear canal.
Fungal infection of the mouth caused by Candida species.
Malignant bone tumor, commonly affecting adolescents.
Softening of bones due to vitamin D deficiency.

Description: Joint condition where bone underneath cartilage dies due to lack of blood flow.
Remedies: Rest, physical therapy, surgery if severe.

Description: Malignant tumor arising from ovarian tissue.
Excessive body fat accumulation posing health risks.
Genetic disorder characterized by brittle bones prone to fracture.

Description: Neonatal conjunctivitis typically caused by infection during birth.

Description: Infection causing inflammation of the air sacs in one or both lungs.
Symptoms: Cough, fever, chest pain, difficulty breathing.
Remedies: Antibiotics for bacterial cause, supportive care.
Advice: Seek early medical care; complete full course of medication.

Description: Progressive neurodegenerative disorder affecting movement.
Symptoms: Tremors, rigidity, slow movement, balance issues.

Description: Open sores on the inner lining of the stomach or duodenum.
Remedies: Eradication of H. pylori, avoid irritants.

Description: Chronic autoimmune skin disease causing red, scaly patches.
Symptoms: Itchy, red plaques with silvery scales.
IsTestOrDoctorRequired: Yes - Clinical diagnosis, biopsy if needed.

Description: Blockage of pulmonary artery by a blood clot.
Symptoms: Sudden shortness of breath, chest pain, rapid pulse.
IsTestOrDoctorRequired: Yes - CT pulmonary angiography, D-dimer test.

Description: Damage to peripheral nerves causing weakness, numbness, and pain.
Advice: Regular monitoring and foot care if diabetic.

Description: Hormonal disorder causing enlarged ovaries with cysts.
Symptoms: Irregular periods, weight gain, acne, infertility.
Remedies: Lifestyle modification, medications to regulate hormones.

Description: Inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis.
Collapsed lung due to air in the pleural space.
Symptoms: Sudden chest pain, shortness of breath.

Description: Inflammation of the pancreas causing abdominal pain.
Symptoms: Severe upper abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting.

Description: Infection caused by Chlamydia psittaci from birds.
Chronic disorder causing enlarged and misshapen bones.
Rare autoimmune blistering disorder of skin and mucous membranes.
Inflammatory disorder causing muscle pain and stiffness.

Description: Group of disorders caused by enzyme deficiencies in heme production.
Lung disease caused by inhalation of dust.
Causes: Exposure to coal, silica, asbestos dust.

Description: A bacterial infection caused by Coxiella burnetii, typically from livestock.

Description: Paralysis affecting all four limbs usually due to spinal cord injury.

Description: A painful pus-filled infection near the tonsils.

Description: A heart rhythm condition with prolonged QT interval on ECG, increasing risk of arrhythmia.

Description: Tear of the tendon connecting quadriceps muscle to the patella.

Description: Excessive intake of the antipsychotic drug quetiapine leading to toxicity.
Respiratory infection caused by Chlamydia psittaci transmitted from birds.

Description: Loss of vision in a quarter of the visual field.

Description: Chronic infection of heart valves caused by Coxiella burnetii.
